bibl.title: Despatch from R. Dorsey Mohun to Josiah Quiney, November 12, 1893
Despatches from United States Consuls in Boma, 1888-1895
bibl.publisher: National Archives and Records Service General Services Administration

div1.note: Indian Bureau Dept of State Mar 26 94
div1.p:
Commercial Agency of the United States,
Lusambo, Kongo Free State Nov. 12 1893.

Mr. R. Dorsey Mohun
To the Department of State.

Left Lusambo Nov. 13
Commandant Dhanis last fight against the Arabs.

Commercial Agency of the United States,
Lusambo, Kongo Free State Nov. 12th 1893.

Honorable Josiah Quincy,
Assistant Secretary of State,
Washington, D.C.

News of a grave character reached here yesterday from Commandanté, Dhanis, who is at Kassongo with the State Troops engaged with the assistance of several thousand natives, in suppressing the Arab slavers.

It seems these Arabs have bought from a trading house, either on Lake Nyassa or the South Eastern end of Lake Tanganyika many rifles (repeating) and an enormous amount of ammunition (cartridges, powder, etc). During the middle of October they arrived near Kassongo, mustering it is estimated 10,000 guns. The Commandant attacked their boma, or
or palisaded fort, but were unable to dislodge them. Not having enough ammunition he has not been able to repeat the assault. During the attack Captain Ponthier (who distinguished himself during 1889-90-91-92 as Van der Kuckhoven's second in the Ouelle Bomakandi Rivers) was severely wounded in both legs and Lieut Lange in the foot & 28 soldiers killed. Commandant Dhanis has asked for re-enforcements from Stanley Falls, Basako, & Lere. I put what force I had with me, at the disposition of the Government and to-morrow morning Novr 13th leave with a caravan of 575 persons for Nyangawé & Kassongo, and expect to arrive at the latter place in 20 days, by marching 10 hours a day.

Respectfully
R. Dorsey Mohun
Commercial Agent
